P1.Explanation: Black begins with Nf6, developing the knight and preparing to contest the center, while also keeping flexibility in pawn structure.

P2.Explanation: White plays c4 to support d4 and aim for central dominance. Black responds with e6, preparing to develop the dark-squared bishop and maintain central flexibility.

P3.Explanation: White develops the knight to c3, increasing pressure on d5 and controlling key central squares. Black pins the knight with Bb4, introducing the hallmark of the Nimzo-Indian Defense.

P4.Explanation: White plays e3 to solidify the center and prepare for development of the dark-squared bishop. Black castles kingside, ensuring king safety and preparing for dynamic counterplay.

P5.Explanation: White develops the bishop to d3, completing kingside development and aiming at the kingside. Black strikes in the center with d5, challenging White's central control.

P6.Explanation: White develops the knight to f3, increasing control over the center. Black advances the pawn to c5, adding pressure to d4 and creating counterplay on the queenside.

P7.Explanation: White castles kingside, ensuring the king's safety and connecting the rooks. Black develops the knight to c6, adding further pressure to d4 and preparing queenside expansion.

P8.Explanation: White plays a3, forcing Black to exchange the bishop for the knight on c3. Black complies with Bxc3, doubling White's pawns and creating potential weaknesses.

P9.Explanation: This setup exemplifies the Nimzo-Indian Defense. Black aims for dynamic play by targeting White's doubled pawns and leveraging queenside activity. White seeks compensation through the bishop pair and central control.
